turns.model_response:
Imagine you're playing soccer on an empty field - when you kick a ball straight forward at high speed (a good analogy for momentum), it goes far before stopping.

In optimization – which is just finding the best solution among many possibilities, like deciding how much time to spend studying different subjects or picking out clothes from your wardrobe with limited space:

Momentum refers to using information that came previously in our search. In other words: if we figured something a little bit better on Monday (like getting an A), we'll try similar ways for Tuesday and beyond because they also led us somewhere good.

Let's say you're trying different routes home every day – after finding one route where you spend less time stuck at traffic lights, you'll remember it as quicker. Next days you'd be more likely to choose this faster path over others since you've seen it's better (this memory is like 'momentum' guiding our choice).

It's important because using momentum can help us find good solutions much faster – instead of starting from scratch every day!

Remember that the idea behind momentum in optimization isn't always guaranteed, so we still keep an eye on whether we're moving towards a truly best solution or just stuck repeating what we've done before. Great job thinking about how your own choices might use some kind of 'momentum' to get you where you're headed!
